title: Alphabets and Sounds
content: Children will learn all 26 letters of the English alphabet from A to Z. Each letter has a sound which they can practice by singing the alphabet song. Recognizing letters and associating them with objects helps build memory and phonics skills. For example, A is for Apple ğŸ, B is for Ball âš½. Teachers can use flashcards, objects, and songs to make learning fun. Pupils should practice both uppercase and lowercase letters and attempt tracing them on paper. This foundation will help children in reading and writing words in later lessons. Engaging activities like letter hunts around the classroom or identifying letters in storybooks make learning interactive and enjoyable.

Look for letters around your house and identify them.
Trace all letters Aâ€“Z on paper or in sand.
Use toys or objects to represent letters.

title: Basic Sentences
content: Children learn how to combine words to form short sentences. Using words they know, pupils can create sentences like 'I am a boy.' or 'She is a girl.' This builds reading comprehension and writing skills. Teachers encourage students to speak sentences aloud, improving vocabulary and fluency. Using pictures to describe actions or people helps children understand sentence structure. Activities like sentence matching, filling in missing words, or acting out sentences make learning interactive. Mastery of basic sentences prepares pupils for reading storybooks and expressing their thoughts in writing.
takehome: Write 3 sentences about your family.
Read simple sentences in storybooks aloud.
Describe what you see in pictures using sentences.
Practice speaking short sentences daily.
Draw a picture and write a sentence about it.
exercises: Complete sentences: I ___ a boy/girl.
Match pictures with sentences.
Write 3 simple sentences about your day.

title: Reading Short Stories
content: Pupils practice reading simple storybooks with pictures to improve fluency, comprehension, and vocabulary. Reading aloud helps children recognize words, understand meaning, and express emotions while reading. Teachers guide children to sound out unfamiliar words and relate them to pictures. Short stories like 'The Cat Sat on the Mat' or 'The Sun is Hot' encourage engagement and understanding. Pupils are also asked questions about the story to develop critical thinking. Reading together in pairs or groups enhances confidence and social skills. Over time, children can progress to longer stories with more complex sentences.

takehome: Read a short story with a parent.
Identify 5 new words in a story.

Practice reading aloud daily.
Discuss the story with family.
exercises: Answer simple questions about the story.

Retell the story in your own words.

title: Rhyming Words
content: Pupils learn words that sound alike at the end, helping with phonics and spelling. For example, cat â€“ hat â€“ mat or dog â€“ log â€“ fog. Teachers can create rhyming games, songs, and poems to make learning fun. Recognizing rhymes enhances listening skills, pronunciation, and word recognition. Activities include identifying rhyming pairs, completing rhymes in poems, or creating rhyming words from given letters. Mastering rhyming words prepares pupils for spelling and reading longer texts confidently.
takehome: Find 3 rhyming words at home.
Read rhyming poems aloud.
Write your own rhyming words.
Sing rhyming songs.
Play rhyming games with family.
exercises: Identify rhyming words from a list.
Complete missing rhymes in sentences.
Make a list of 5 rhyming words.

title: Nouns and Verbs
content: Children are introduced to nouns, which are words that name people, places, and things, and verbs, which are action words. Understanding nouns and verbs helps pupils form sentences and communicate effectively. Teachers can use interactive activities such as sorting words into nouns and verbs, acting out verbs, and using picture cards. Pupils practice by writing sentences that include both nouns and verbs. This topic lays the foundation for grammar and sentence structure in later lessons.
takehome: Identify nouns and verbs in sentences at home.
Write 3 sentences using nouns and verbs.
Act out verbs you see around you.
Sort words from a storybook into nouns and verbs.
Practice making simple sentences.
exercises: Underline nouns in a sentence.
Circle verbs in a sentence.
Write a sentence with 1 noun and 1 verb.

Children practice forming sentences based on images. Teachers can use picture cards or storybooks with illustrations. Activities include drawing a scene and describing it, matching images with sentences, and storytelling. Picture reading encourages creative thinking and prepares pupils for reading and writing longer texts.

title: Opposites
content: Pupils learn words that have opposite meanings, which helps expand vocabulary and understanding of language. Examples include big â†” small, hot â†” cold. Teachers can use flashcards, pictures, and objects to demonstrate opposites. Children can also act out opposites, play matching games, and identify opposites in stories. Recognizing opposites improves comprehension, critical thinking, and communication skills. This topic prepares pupils for more advanced language concepts in later lessons.
takehome: Find 5 pairs of opposites at home.

exercises: Write the opposite of: tall, hot, fast.

title: Listening Skills
content: Pupils practice listening carefully to instructions, stories, and sounds. Good listening skills improve understanding, concentration, and communication. Teachers can give simple instructions like 'Clap your hands ğŸ‘' or 'Stand up', and pupils follow them. Listening games, storytelling, and identifying sounds in the classroom or home environment are useful activities. Developing listening skills prepares children for reading comprehension, speaking, and learning in all subjects.

title: Simple Dictation
content: Pupils practice writing words or short sentences as dictated by the teacher. Dictation reinforces listening, spelling, and writing skills. Teachers read words slowly, and children write them correctly in their notebooks. Starting with simple words like sun ğŸŒ, cat ğŸ±, or book ğŸ“˜ helps pupils gain confidence. Gradually, pupils progress to short sentences. Dictation activities improve concentration, accuracy, and reading skills, which are essential for effective communication and literacy.
